title: 111_hr81
content: The table of contents includes sections on the Shark Conservation Act of 2010, International Fisheries Agreement, and Miscellaneous provisions. Each section outlines specific titles and amendments related to fisheries management and conservation efforts. The "Shark Conservation Act of 2010" is cited as the title. Amendment of the High Seas Driftnet Fishing Moratorium Protection Act is included. The High Seas Driftnet Fishing Moratorium Protection Act is amended to include shark conservation measures, such as prohibiting the removal of shark fins and discarding shark carcasses at sea. Additionally, efforts are made to enter into international agreements for shark conservation. The High Seas Driftnet Fishing Moratorium Protection Act is amended to include shark conservation measures, such as prohibiting the removal of shark fins and discarding shark carcasses at sea. Additionally, efforts are made to enter into international agreements for shark conservation, including measures comparable to those of the United States. The High Seas Driftnet Fishing Moratorium Protection Act is amended to include shark conservation measures, such as prohibiting the removal of shark fins and discarding shark carcasses at sea. The amendments involve restructuring and reorganizing the text to clarify and enhance the provisions related to shark conservation. The High Seas Driftnet Fishing Moratorium Protection Act is amended to include shark conservation measures, requiring nations with fishing vessels targeting or incidentally catching sharks in international waters to adopt regulations comparable to those of the United States. The Secretary of Commerce will begin identifying nations that do not meet these conservation standards. The High Seas Driftnet Fishing Moratorium Protection Act is amended to include shark conservation measures, requiring nations with fishing vessels targeting or incidentally catching sharks in international waters to adopt regulations comparable to those of the United States. Nations failing to meet these standards will be identified by the Secretary of Commerce within a year of the Act's enactment. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to prohibit the removal of shark fins at sea, possession of detached fins on fishing vessels, transfer of fins between vessels without the carcass, and landing of fins not attached to the corresponding carcass. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to include a rebuttable presumption regarding the transfer of shark fins not naturally attached to the carcass, and the landing of shark fins exceeding five percent of the total weight of shark carcasses. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to include a savings clause for individuals engaged in commercial fishing for smooth dogfish. This exemption applies to those fishing within 50 nautical miles from the baseline of a State, with certain conditions on the weight of smooth dogfish fins landed. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to include a savings clause for individuals engaged in commercial fishing for smooth dogfish within 50 nautical miles from the baseline of a State. The term "State" is defined in section 803 of Public Law 103-206. SEC. 104. OFFSET OF IMPLEMENTATION COST. Amends the Interjurisdictional Fisheries Act of 1986 to allocate $2,500,000 for each of fiscal years 2011 and 2012. TITLE II--INTERNATIONAL FISHERIES AGREEMENT. This title may be cited as the "International Fisheries Agreement Clarification Act". SEC. 202. INTERNATIONAL FISHERY AGREEMENT. The Secretary of Commerce and the New England Fishery Management Council may consider decisions made under the United States-Canada Transboundary Resource Sharing Understanding for rebuilding fish stocks, and establish catch levels within their respective geographic areas. The Secretary of Commerce and the New England Fishery Management Council may establish catch levels within their geographic areas covered by the Understanding, exceeding required levels under the Northeast Multispecies Fishery Management Plan if overfishing is stopped immediately, fishing mortality ensures rebuilding within a specified time period, and the catch levels are consistent with the Understanding. SEC. 203. APPLICATION WITH OTHER LAWS. This title does not change the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act or the authority of the Secretary of Commerce under that Act. SEC. 204. EFFECTIVE DATE. Section 202 applies to fishing years starting after April 30, 2010, with a special rule for 2012. TITLE III--MISCELLANEOUS. Technical corrections to the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Convention Implementation Act. Section 503 of the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Convention Implementation Act is amended to clarify the employment status of individuals serving as Commissioners. They are not considered Federal employees except for specific purposes related to injury compensation or tort claims liability. The employment status of individuals serving as Commissioners under the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Convention Implementation Act is clarified. They are not Federal employees except for injury compensation or tort claims liability. SEC. 302 of the Pacific Whiting Act of 2006 is amended to limit the number of scientific experts to no more than 2. Additionally, individuals appointed under specific sections of the Act are clarified to not be considered Federal employees, except for injury compensation or tort claims liability. The Secretary of Commerce may issue regulations for replacing or rebuilding qualified vessels under specific sections of the Department of Commerce Appropriations Act, 2005.
